channel.title: Found an important packetType
channel.description:
[code]case 21: //third click NPC break;[/code]
This is not origionally in any source, not that I know of. This case happens when you click, for example, 'Teleport' on a mage of zamorak. correct me if i'm wrong, It returns the case, but no packetsize, making it impossible to get the NPCslot. The client will have to somehow return the packetsize, so we can get the correct NPC slot.
Does anybody know how to do this?

item.title: Found an important packetType
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Javacisnotrecognized:

The effect is that if you place even one of them incorrectly, you lose your admin status, you can’t walk, and if you try to say anything half your server becomes corrupted.

I’d just restart…

But if it affects the files, i’d have to make a backup. (which I know wont happen)

The way I experiment with these symbals | &~<< >> is by making a command of math operations. I expect these symbols are for numbering.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

:[br][size=1]Posted at: November 16, 2006, 09:18:50 PM[/size][hr]Can you tell me what those | &~<< >> things mean? I know the first of those are booleans, but I never seen them used outside an if statement…

item.title: Found an important packetType
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:2, topic:26079”]instream.readUnsignedByte();
instream.readUnsignedByteA();
other stuff like that. If you want to be able to figure it out properly, you need to understand shit like this:

if(numBits == bitOffset) { buffer[bytePos] &= ~ bitMaskOut[bitOffset]; buffer[bytePos] |= value & bitMaskOut[bitOffset]; } else { buffer[bytePos] &= ~ (bitMaskOut[numBits]<<(bitOffset - numBits)); buffer[bytePos] |= (value&bitMaskOut[numBits]) << (bitOffset - numBits); } [/quote]

The two inStreams, you have suggested, still do not read anything. readUnsignedByteA(), returns 128, while the other one returns 0.

Read full topic

item.title: Found an important packetType
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

instream.readUnsignedByte();
instream.readUnsignedByteA();
other stuff like that. If you want to be able to figure it out properly, you need to understand shit like this:

if(numBits == bitOffset) {
			buffer[bytePos] &= ~ bitMaskOut[bitOffset];
			buffer[bytePos] |= value & bitMaskOut[bitOffset];
		} else {
			buffer[bytePos] &= ~ (bitMaskOut[numBits]<<(bitOffset - numBits));
			buffer[bytePos] |= (value&bitMaskOut[numBits]) << (bitOffset - numBits);
		}

Read full topic
